content:
The COVID-19 pandemic has had a significant impact on the CFL in terms of revenue and marketing strategies. The league suspended its season in 2020, leading to significant losses in revenue from ticket sales, broadcasting rights, and merchandise sales. The cancellation of the 2020 Grey Cup also had a significant impact on the league's finances.

In response to the pandemic, the CFL has had to adjust its marketing strategies to fit the new normal and the needs of its fans. The league has had to invest more in digital marketing, social media campaigns, and virtual fan events to engage with fans and maintain fan loyalty, especially in a time when fans' physical presence at games is impossible.

The CFL has also introduced new measures to address the financial challenges caused by the pandemic. This includes initiatives such as securing emergency funding from the Canadian federal government, renegotiating broadcast rights with media partners, and considering the creation of a global football league.

Overall, the CFL has had to be creative and flexible in developing new marketing strategies and adapting to the challenging circumstances of the pandemic to maintain its brand, support its fans and build its revenue streams.
